title: File:DuelPersonalitytitle.jpg
body:
Title card of the 1964 cartoon, Duel Personality, taken from DVD, but low-resolution.

1. This screenshot is of the title card and does not feature any footage from the actual cartoon. It also lists cartoon's title and credits, therefore containing information that may be of interest to some, as well as showcasing some nice artwork of the age.

2. The screenshot is being used for informational purposes only, and its use is not believed to detract from the original film in any way possible.

3. The screenshot is of lower resolution and quality than the original film. Consequently, copies made from it should be of inferior quality.

4. No public-domain images or free images have been located for this or similar content.

5. The screenshot does not limit the copyright owners' rights to distribute the film on television or DVDs in any way whatsoever.

Does anybody actually read these or do the "bots" automatically and arbitrarily decide what's "disputed?"

body:
TITLE: Optimum BSE detectors in ESEM

DATE: May, 2008

CREATOR: Gerry Danilatos

SOURCE: ESEM Research, 

KEY WORDS: ESEM, optimum BSE detectors, backscattered electrons, scintillating detectors

DESCRIPTION: Optimum geometry backscattered electron detectors in ESEM. Clear plastic light pipes coated with scintillating material, abutting the PLA1 aperture for maximum collection efficiency, while gas flows from specimen chamber at pressure p, to intermediate stage out at p. Electron beam passes through vacuum at p above final lens and PLA2 before it strikes the specimen

title: File:El Cabrillo Courtyard.JPG
body: Rationale for use on wikipedia:1.The structure depicted is listed in the National Register of Historic Places. The image is of the historic interior courtyard of the building. No free use images are available of the interior courtyard which is not a public space. 2.The image does not in any way limit the ability of the copyright owners to market or sell their product. In fact, the photograph is used to actively market units in the building for rental, and attention given to the building and photographs on wikipedia only enhances the ability to market and sell the product.3.The image is only used once and is rendered in low resolution to avoid piracy.4.The image has been published outside Wikipedia; see source above.5.The image meets general Wikipedia content requirements and is encyclopedic.6.The image meets Wikipedia's media-specific policy.7.The image is needed to identify the building for educational purposes in an encyclopedia entry and significantly improves the quality of the article. 8.The image has a brief description that identifies the image, notes the source, and provides attribution to the copyright holder. Use of image in the article complies with Wikipedia non-free content policy and fair use under United States copyright law as described above.

title: File:Firewall construction.jpg
body: Firewalls, protruding THROUGH a roof, with sheet metal flashing on top to preserve the building envelope, separating a building into separate parts. Firewalls are constructed of concrete or concrete blocks, in such a manner as to obtain a fire-resistance rating, as well as to ensure that if there is structural collapse as a result of a fire on one side, this collapse cannot carry over to the other side. Codewise, one may thus reduce the area, as if each segment is a separate building, to avoid the cost of having to install a sprinkler system. Penetrant must be run in such a way as to avoid damage to a firewall. Firestop in firewalls typically have to achieve T-Ratings equivalent to the fire-resistance rating of the wall.\n\n

body: Picture of the Steamer Sirius, a tourist boat that transversed the Grasse River and St.Lawrence River in the 1910s. It sunk on the Grasse River when the tourist on-board rushed to one side of the boat to catch a glimpse of a beaver, and caused the boat to capsize. Picture is scanned from a postcard published in 1915 and is part of my family's photo history.\n\n

title: File:GriffithandWhite2.JPG
body:
Author: Virgin ISlands Legislature photographer

I really do not understand what you all want and how to prove it to you. I say I am the photographer of the images and that they are used with my permission but that is not good enough for you. I wrote the article for Senator White and because I have allowed the Legislature of the Virgin Islands to use his biographic information youu accuse ME< THE AUTHOR of plagarism? How is one supposed to prove the origin of materials to you. I scour your site and the instructions and do as you ask but nothing seems to be good enough. Can someone PLEASE tell me what I am supposed to do? Call me or something, and tell me what you need. My hand on the bible? People to call you and say I wrote it? What? phone number redacted. I know you have not had anyone tell you that you are violating any copyright because I am the only person who can tell you that!!!

Karl Callwood

title: File:HMAS gawler crest.png
body:
The image is of the ship badge for HMAS Gawler, one or several naval vessels of the Royal Australian Navy. The ship badge is a logo used to represent the ship, and applies to all active or previous ships bearing the name. The image was originally located at http://www.navy.gov.au/ships/gawler/default.html, but following a reorganisation of the RAN website in August 2008, can now be found at http://www.navy.gov.au/w/index.php/Category:Badges

As several Australian warships may have used this name and ship badge over history, the image will likely be used in multiple articles. A fair use rationale should be provided for each article.

Gawler

title: File:Hamilton College seal.jpg
body:
The seal of Hamilton College. The text around the outside reads, "Seal of Hamilton College, founded 1812." The banner over the scene depicted reads "Gnothi Seauton" ("Know thyself" in Greek), and the words that the angel points to are "Lux et Veritas" ("Light and Truth" in Latin).

I am currently searching for a better-quality version of this seal, but this is a difficult task as the college is phasing it out in favor of their more modern logo (as can be seen on the College's web site). If you have a seal of higher quality in your possession, feel free to upload it in place of this image.

File:InspectorTeal.jpg
body: Screencapture taken from the DVD set "The Saint: The Early Episodes", copyright 2004 by A&E Home Video and Carlton. The episode pictured is "Iris", an episode of The Saint, copyright 1963 ITC Entertainment and Carlton. This image, which is cropped from a complete screencapture, has been created in order to illustrate the fictional character Claud Eustace Teal for the article of this name. This image has been created as no book covers or other fair use illustrations showing Teal are known to exist, and that Ivor Dean's portrayal of Teal is the best known of this character. He also physically resembles the character as described by Leslie Charteris. Under the rules of fair use, screencaptures may be used for discussing "for identification" of a film/TV episode "or its contents". The character of Inspector Teal, and the actor portraying him qualify as contents of this production. As such this image may also be used to illustrate the article on Ivor Dean if no alternative is located.\n\n

title: File:Kikai-india.jpg
body:
Cover of India by Hiroh Kikai, at reduced size. Design ©Misuzu Shobou, incorporating a photograph © Hiroh Kikai. Size deliberately reduced. -- Hoary 09:12, 16 June 2006 (UTC)

Looking at the top of the cover as scanned, one might think that something went seriously wrong in the scanning process, or that something is seriously wrong with the scanner. But in fact the title "India" is printed on the dust cover in such a way that it does look as if it is out of focus. -- Hoary 06:04, 17 June 2006 (UTC)

This image, Kikai-india.jpg, is being linked from Hiroh Kikai; though the picture is subject to copyright I (Hoary) think it is covered by the U.S. fair use laws because:

body:
TV screenshot of two Kromaggs from the TV show Sliders, episode Invasion (Sliders). I took the screenshot myself. Copyright is probably owned by those who own the licence of Sliders, but I believe a limited number of copyrighted screenshots is allowed as fair use.

This is one frame from an episode of one episode of the show (episode "Invasion" of "Sliders"). A single frame is not going to take away from the ability of the copyright owners to commercialize the product. The image is a picture of the "Kromagg" characters used in the television show, so it provides a picture to identify the subject of the Kromagg article.

title: File:LibertySeatedLegendHalfDime.jpg
body: The 1862 Half Dime. As a U.S. coin, the design is in the public domain, and per : "Also note that in the United States, reproductions of two-dimensional artwork which is in the public domain because of age do not generate a new copyright — for example, a straight-on photograph of the Mona Lisa would not be considered copyrighted (see Bridgeman v. Corel). Scans of images alone do not generate new copyrights — they merely inherit the copyright status of the image they are reproducing." Since this is simply a straight-on photo or scan, with no creative aspect involved, it should not be subject to copyright as per this precedent.\n\n

title: File:Los Angeles Plaza ca. 1890.jpg
body: Rationale for use on wikipedia:1.The structure depicted is the center of the Los Angeles Plaza Historic Distict, as it appeared in 1890. This historic image depicts the plaza during its period of historic significance. No known free use images are available of the plaza during this era. 2.The image does not in any way limit the ability of the copyright owners to market or sell their product.3.The image is only used once and is rendered in low resolution to avoid piracy.4.The image has been published outside Wikipedia; see source above.5.The image meets general Wikipedia content requirements and is encyclopedic.6.The image meets Wikipedia's media-specific policy.7.The image is needed to identify the site for educational purposes in an encyclopedia entry and significantly improves the quality of the article. 8.The image has a brief description that identifies the image, notes the source, and provides attribution to the copyright holder. Use of image in the article complies with Wikipedia non-free content policy and fair use under United States copyright law as described above.

body:
Scanned image of promotional photo from the booklet of the CD release of Lowlife's "Eternity Road"

This image, LowlifeBand.jpg, is scanned from a promotional photograph included in the booklet for the CD, Eternity Road: Reflections of Lowlife 85-95. The image depicts the band, and is used here in good faith to illustrate the subject of the article, Lowlife. The photograph was copyrighted by the band's original record label, Nightshift Records (catalogue now owned by LTM). This photograph cannot be replaced by a free-licensed image as the band is no longer in existence and no other image that depicts the band can be located.-Hal Raglan (talk) 02:19, 3 January 2008 (UTC)

title: File:MozartPianoConcertoK5372ndMvtOpeningAutographVersion.PNG
body:
The opening eight bars of the second movement of Mozart's Piano Concerto K. 537. This image shows the piano part as it appears in Mozart's autograph (hand-written) version, in which the notes for the left hand are left for the player to improvise. Source is Braunbehrens (1990) Mozart in Vienna, p. 6.

This music was written over 200 years ago and is in the public domain.

Digital image of the notes made by Opus33 using Sibelius software. The image is hereby released by Opus33 into the public domain.

title: File:NewBlankDrugChart.svg
body:
SVG version of original by .

From the original description:This new version of the psychoactive drug chart background graphic expands the antipsychotic ellipse into a full circle, balancing against the hallucinogen circle as the stimulant circle balances against the depressants. Whereas the old drug chart focused on an overlapping of three circles with the antipsychotic ellipse added as a "second thought", the new chart is an even mix of four overlapping circles. While this adds the complexity of new color regions, and a shrinkage of some previous regions, I believe that it is a move in the right direction. (I also feel that the new chart is much more aesthetically pleasing to the eye).

title: File:NewarkBasin BoontonFormation.jpg
body:
Section of the Boonton Formation exposed in a road cut in Pequannock Township, New Jersey. The image shows three distinct layers within this section of the formation. The bottom layer appears to be composed of flaggy purple siltstone and mudstone, while the middle layer is composed of conglomerate (mainly large pebbles surrounded by purple sandstone/siltstone). The top layer appears to be either a carbonate bearing siltstone or some sort of irregular carbonate concretion with a light gray coloration.

Image taken by me, July 24th, 2010.

title: File:Old Spanish rug.jpg
body:
Spain, 16th century

The Textile Museum R44.2.1 --Acquired by George Hewitt Myers in 1920234 x 165 cm

Combining stylistic influences from Europe and the Islamic world, the pattern of this 16th-century Spanish carpet resembles Gothic silks. Within a hexagonal grid, each large blossom is symmetrical along a vertical axis of reflection. The green bands of illusionary interlace throw off the field pattern's symmetry of reflection and glide reflection.

All of the borders are to be viewed from the same direction. They display designs that are symmetrical or asymmetrical. The side borders are symmetrical to one another by reflection. The top and bottom borders show translation of two designs, a lion and a tree. 

http://mathforum.org/geometry/rugs/gallery/06.html

File:Ottoman1517.png
body: The crescents used on flags, banners and standards during the 16th and 17th centuries are "fatter" than we are used to seeing on Ottoman flags, as seen on flags and standards that exist in museums today. Take a look at the standard of Selim I. For this flag, only a description survives: "A red flag with a green circle and three crescents". As such, I have based the placement on the Egyptian flags of Mohammed Ali.\n\n

title: File:Ouchterlony Double Diffusion.JPG
body: This is a self taken picture of an Ouchterlony Double Diffusion method. The central well has an antibody. The surrounding wells have decreasing concentration of the corresponding antigen, labelled Neat (1:1), 1:2, 1:4, 1:8, 1:16 and 1:32, clockwise from top. It is clear here that the line stops at 1:8, which is taken as the titre value.\n\n

Screen shot from the 1978 TV movie KISS Meets of the Phantom of the Park. The film is copyrighted 1978, Hanna-Barbera. This screenshot was obtained from Lynn's KISS Dominion, specifically the gallery located at http://www.kissdominion.com/phantgal.htm. Permission to use the screen shot was requested and obtained via email.

This is a low-resolution screenshot being used in an article about the film, and is used to to identify/discuss a particular scene or concept relating to the film itself. The movie is currently out of print, so use of this image does not interfere with the ability of the copyright holder to market the product.

title: File:Phase diag iron carbon-color temp.png
body:
A combination of :Image:Phase diag iron carbon.PNG and :Image:Blackbody Horizontal.pngFrom :Image:Phase diag iron carbon.PNG:

Iron-carbon phase diagram under atmospheric pressure

This diagram is limited by pure iron on the left and by iron carbide on the right. The mains phases are:

We can see a eutectic and a eutectoid; these phases crystallise as a stacking of fine strips of pure phases (iron and cementite) in case of the eutectoid, or a pure iron containing small balls of cementite for the eutectic. Although it is heterogeneous, these phases behave like homogeneous pure bodies.

Steel is between 0 and 2.06 mass percent of carbon. Cast iron is between 2.06 and 6.67%.

Author : Christophe Dang Ngoc Chan

title: File:Pup On A Picnic title.JPG
body:
Taken from DVD, the title card of 1953's "Pup on a Picnic."

1. No free or public-domain images or images have been found for this content.

2. This screenshot is of the cartoon's title card and doesn't show any of the actual cartoon itself. It also displays the cartoon's title and credits, thus giving credit to those who worked on the cartoon.

3. The screenshot does not limit the copyright owners' rights to distribute the film on television or DVDs in any way.

4. The screenshot is being used for informational purposes only, and its use is not believed to detract from the original film in any way possible.

5. The screenshot is of lower resolution and quality than the original film. Thus, copies made from it will be of even lower quality.

Additions and alterations to the images are direct translations of the Hebrew text only.

title: File:Quantum periodic table.jpg
body: The periodic table organized in the pattern of quantum mechanics electron orbital filling. Each coupled box of two elements are separated by a diagonal line. The top element has just one electron of spin up orientation while the bottom element has two electrons one of spin up and another in spin down. The orbitals are labeled s,p,d, and f to represent different volume probabilities of an electron at a given moment. This quantum periodic table has been presented as the most mathematically organized.\n\n

title: File:RFA Probability Plot.png
body:
Created by Dragons flight using a year's worth of RFA data (February 06-07).

Image shows the probability that an RFA will end successfully as a function of the number of days that the RFA has been open and the percentage of votes that are in support at that time.

The wispy line at ~60% support is entirely due to the highly unusual promotion of Carnildo 3.

title: File:RichlandWaBadgerTrail-C.jpg
body:
Photos of Richland, Washington taken on a lovely 50°F Sunday, January 15, 2006 for the specific purpose of being uploaded to the Wikipedia. All rights are released; they are henceforth & forever in the public domain until the sun does not rise in the east and the rivers no longer run to the sea. 

The view from Badger Mountain Centennial Preserve shows Red Mountain in the foreground and Rattlesnake Mountain beyond it. 

The 1.2-mile long, 800-foot in elevation trail on Badger Mountain is a new reserve within the city boundary or Growth Management Area for Richland. It was built by Volunteers who broke new trail by hand in October 2005. Community members from Richland and the surrounding area secured protection for this important area above the Tri-Cities. The Friends of Badger Mountain acquired the property, preserving it for the public. The Trust for Public Land, Benton County, the City of Richland and the Friends of Badger Mountain worked together to buy 574 acres to create the Badger Mountain Centennial Preserve, to be maintained in its natural state.

RichlandWaBadgerTrail-C.jpg

title: File:Rotating Ring Cyl Ring2RingRadar.png
body:
This schematic figure illustrates the concept of radar distance between two Langevin observers in Minkowski spacetime. 

Langevin observers rotate rigidly around r = 0 (in a standard cylindrical chart) with angular velocity ω.

In the figure, a Langevin observer sends out a radar pulse at event A which hits another Langevin observer riding the same rotating ring at B′ which returns to the first observer at event A′;. To determine the radar distance, he divides the elapsed time (as measured by an ideal clock which he carries) by two.

At right, the ring is rotating counterclockwise. At left, it is rotating clockwise. Equal but oppositely directed rotation will result in different values for the radar distance. In other words, a pair of Langevin observers riding a rotating ring who each determine radar distances to their peer will obtain different values. This illustrates the fact that radar distance "in the large" is not symmetric.

This figure was created by  using Xfig to export a png image; the labels were added using the GIMP.

title: File:STUKA OVER SEDAN.JPG
body:
Photograph published in:Hooton, E.R (2007). Luftwaffe at War; Blitzkrieg in the West. London: Chervron/Ian Allen. ISBN 978-1-85780-272-6. Photographer not identified, so UK Copyright contended to have lapsed 50 years after publication. 

Fair Use Rationale: The image is taken during World War 2, Copyright is difficult to establish. Since the image is a depiction of a historical figure in low resolution, and an unrestricted image is difficult to obtain the image is probably fair use in the article Battle of France

title: File:SafetySecondTitle.JPG
body:
Low-res screenshot of title card of the Tom & Jerry cartoon Safety Second (1950).

1. This screenshot is of the title card and does not feature any footage from the actual cartoon. It also lists cartoon's title and credits, therefore containing information that may be of interest to some, as well as showcasing some nice artwork of the age.

2. The screenshot is being used for informational purposes only, and its use is not believed to detract from the original film in any way possible.

3. The screenshot is of lower resolution and quality than the original film. Consequently, copies made from it should be of inferior quality.

4. No public-domain images or free images have been located for this or similar content.

5. The screenshot does not limit the copyright owners' rights to distribute the film on television or DVDs in any way whatsoever.
